sections.content: Python is one of the most popular programming languages in the world. Why? It's readable, versatile, powerful, and beginner-friendly. Used by Google, Netflix, NASA, and millions of developers. You can build websites, analyze data, automate tasks, create AI models, and more. Python isn't just for programmersâ€”it's tool for anyone who wants to work smarter.

sections.title: Why Learn Python?
items: Beginner-friendly: Reads almost like English
Versatile: Web dev, data science, automation, AI, more
In-demand: Top skill employers want
Productive: Build more with less code
Community: Massive support and resources
Free: Open source, no licensing costs
Career boost: Python skills increase earning potential

sections.content: Python philosophy: 'There should be one obvious way to do it.' Code should be explicit, readable, and simple. This makes Python easier to learn and maintain than many languages. The Zen of Python emphasizes: beautiful is better than ugly, explicit is better than implicit, simple is better than complex.

sections.title: What You Can Build with Python
items: Web applications: Django, Flask frameworks
Data analysis: Pandas, NumPy for data manipulation
Machine learning: TensorFlow, scikit-learn for AI
Automation scripts: Automate repetitive tasks
APIs: Build services other apps can use
Games: Pygame for game development
Desktop apps: GUI applications with Tkinter
Scrapers: Extract data from websites

sections.title: Setting Up Python
items: Download: python.org - get latest version (3.11+)
Install: Follow installer instructions for your OS
Verify: Open terminal, type 'python --version'
IDE options: VS Code (recommended), PyCharm, Jupyter
VS Code: Free, powerful, great extensions
Python extension: Install Python extension in VS Code
First program: Create file 'hello.py', write code, run it

sections.content: Your first Python program: Open text editor, type 'print("Hello, World!")' and save as hello.py. Run it: open terminal, navigate to file location, type 'python hello.py'. You just wrote and executed Python code. That's it. From here, we build.

sections.title: Learning Approach
items: Type code: Don't just read, actually write it
Experiment: Change things, break things, learn
Practice daily: 30 minutes beats occasional 3-hour sessions
Build projects: Apply concepts to real problems
Debug: Errors are learning opportunities
Google: Every programmer googles constantly
Patience: Programming is learnable skill, not talent

quiz.question: Why is Python popular?
options: Readable, versatile, beginner-friendly, and widely used
quiz.explanation: Python is popular because it's readable (almost like English), versatile (many uses), beginner-friendly, and widely used by major companies.

quiz.question: What's the first step to learning Python?
options: Download and install Python, then start writing code
quiz.explanation: Start by downloading Python from python.org, install it, verify installation, set up an editor (like VS Code), and start writing simple code.

sections.content: Variables store data. That's it. They're containers holding information your program uses. Data types define what kind of information: numbers, text, true/false values, etc. Understanding variables and data types is foundation of all programming. Master these, everything else makes sense.

sections.title: Creating Variables
items: Syntax: variable_name = value
Example: age = 25
Example: name = 'John'
No declaration needed: Python figures out type automatically
Naming rules: Letters, numbers, underscores only
Can't start with number: '2cool' is invalid, 'cool2' is valid
Case-sensitive: 'Name' and 'name' are different variables
Convention: use_lowercase_with_underscores

sections.content: Dynamic typing: Python variables can change type. 'x = 5' (integer), then 'x = "hello"' (string) is valid. Some languages don't allow this. Python's flexibility makes it easier but requires awareness of what type variable currently holds.

sections.title: Basic Data Types
items: int: Whole numbers (5, -10, 1000)
float: Decimal numbers (3.14, -0.5, 2.0)
str: Text/strings ('hello', "Python", 'a')
bool: True or False (boolean logic)
NoneType: None (represents absence of value)
Check type: type(variable) shows data type
Example: type(5) returns <class 'int'>

sections.title: Working with Strings
items: Single or double quotes: 'hello' or "hello" (both work)
Concatenation: 'Hello' + ' ' + 'World' = 'Hello World'
F-strings: f'My age is {age}' (insert variables)
Methods: .upper(), .lower(), .strip(), .split()
Example: name = 'john'; name.upper() returns 'JOHN'
Indexing: name[0] gets first character
Slicing: name[0:2] gets first two characters

sections.title: Working with Numbers
items: Addition: 5 + 3 = 8
Subtraction: 10 - 4 = 6
Multiplication: 7 * 3 = 21
Division: 10 / 2 = 5.0 (always returns float)
Integer division: 10 // 3 = 3 (drops remainder)
Modulo: 10 % 3 = 1 (remainder only)
Exponent: 2 ** 3 = 8 (2 to power of 3)
Order: PEMDAS (Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division, Addition/Subtraction)

sections.title: Type Conversion
items: int(): Convert to integer - int('5') = 5
float(): Convert to float - float('3.14') = 3.14
str(): Convert to string - str(42) = '42'
bool(): Convert to boolean - bool(1) = True
When needed: Adding number and string requires conversion
Example: age = 25; print('I am ' + str(age)) works
Without conversion: print('I am ' + 25) causes error

sections.content: Input from users: input() function gets user input. Always returns string, even if they type number. Example: name = input('What is your name? ') stores their response. For numbers: age = int(input('Enter age: ')) converts string to integer.

quiz.question: What does 'age = 25' do?
quiz.explanation: 'age = 25' creates a variable named 'age' and stores the value 25 in it. Variables are containers that hold data.

quiz.question: What type is returned by input()?
options: String (always, even if user types number)
quiz.explanation: input() always returns a string, even if the user types a number. Use int() or float() to convert if you need a number.

sections.content: Operators perform operations on values. Expressions combine values and operators to produce results. This is how programs make decisions, calculate, and manipulate data. Master operators, you can build complex logic from simple building blocks.

sections.title: Comparison Operators
items: == : Equal to (5 == 5 is True)
!= : Not equal to (5 != 3 is True)
> : Greater than (10 > 5 is True)
< : Less than (3 < 7 is True)
>= : Greater than or equal (5 >= 5 is True)
<= : Less than or equal (4 <= 6 is True)
Result: Always returns True or False (boolean)
Common mistake: Using = instead of == for comparison

sections.content: Single = vs double ==: Single equals (=) assigns value. Double equals (==) compares values. 'x = 5' means set x to 5. 'x == 5' means check if x equals 5. Confusing these is extremely common mistake. Be careful.

sections.title: Logical Operators
items: and: Both must be True (True and True = True)
or: At least one must be True (True or False = True)
not: Reverses boolean (not True = False)
Example: age > 18 and age < 65 (between 18 and 65)
Example: day == 'Saturday' or day == 'Sunday' (weekend)
Example: not is_weekend (checks if NOT weekend)
Combine: Use parentheses for complex conditions

sections.title: Assignment Operators
items: = : Basic assignment (x = 5)
+= : Add and assign (x += 3 means x = x + 3)
-= : Subtract and assign (x -= 2 means x = x - 2)
*= : Multiply and assign (x *= 4 means x = x * 4)
/= : Divide and assign (x /= 2 means x = x / 2)
Shorthand: Cleaner code, common in loops
Example: score += 10 adds 10 to current score

sections.title: Membership Operators
items: in: Checks if value exists in sequence
not in: Checks if value doesn't exist
Example: 'a' in 'apple' returns True
Example: 5 in [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] returns True
Example: 'z' not in 'hello' returns True
Use: Checking if item exists before using it
Very useful with strings, lists, dictionaries

sections.content: Operator precedence: Operations execute in specific order. Parentheses first, then exponents, then multiplication/division, then addition/subtraction. When in doubt, use parentheses to make order explicit. '2 + 3 * 4' = 14 (multiply first). '(2 + 3) * 4' = 20 (add first).

sections.title: Practical Examples
items: Checking age range: age >= 13 and age <= 19 (teenager)
Validating input: len(password) >= 8 (password long enough)
Discount eligibility: is_member or purchase > 100
Access control: is_admin and not is_banned
Data validation: email != '' and '@' in email
Counter: count += 1 (increment counter)
Combining: Complex logic from simple operators

quiz.question: What's the difference between = and ==?
quiz.explanation: Single = assigns value (x = 5 sets x to 5). Double == compares values (x == 5 checks if x equals 5). Very important distinction!

quiz.question: What does 'and' require?
quiz.explanation: 'and' requires BOTH conditions to be True. 'or' requires at least ONE to be True. 'not' reverses the boolean value.

sections.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code. Instead of writing same code repeatedly, write it once in function, then call function whenever needed. Functions make code: cleaner, easier to maintain, easier to test, easier to understand. Professional code is function-heavy. Learn this well.

sections.title: Creating Functions
items: Syntax: def function_name():
Indent: Code inside function must be indented
Example: def greet(): print('Hello!')
Calling: greet() executes the function
Naming: Use descriptive names (calculate_total, not func1)
Convention: lowercase_with_underscores
Docstring: Optional description of what function does

sections.content: DRY principle: Don't Repeat Yourself. If you're copying and pasting code, you probably need a function. Each time you need that logic, call the function. Update once, changes apply everywhere. This is professional programming.

sections.title: Parameters and Arguments
items: Parameters: Variables in function definition
Arguments: Actual values passed when calling
Example: def greet(name): print(f'Hello {name}')
Calling: greet('John') passes 'John' as argument
Multiple parameters: def add(a, b): return a + b
Default values: def greet(name='Guest'): ...
If no argument provided, default value used

sections.title: Return Values
items: return: Sends value back to caller
Example: def add(a, b): return a + b
Using: result = add(5, 3) stores 8 in result
No return: Function returns None by default
Multiple returns: return x, y returns tuple
Early return: Can return before end of function
Return stops execution: Code after return doesn't run

sections.content: Function scope: Variables created inside function only exist inside function. Can't access them from outside. Variables from outside can be read inside but not modified (without 'global'). This prevents accidental changes and keeps code organized.

sections.title: Built-in Functions
items: print(): Display output
len(): Get length of sequence
type(): Check data type
int(), str(), float(): Convert types
input(): Get user input
range(): Generate number sequence
sum(): Add numbers in sequence
max(), min(): Find largest/smallest value
abs(): Absolute value
round(): Round number

sections.title: Best Practices
items: One purpose: Function should do one thing well
Descriptive names: Name should explain what function does
Keep short: If too long, break into smaller functions
Document: Add docstring explaining purpose
Return, don't print: Return values for flexibility
Consistent: Similar operations should use similar patterns
Test: Test functions with different inputs

quiz.question: What's the DRY principle?
options: Don't Repeat Yourself - use functions for reusable code
quiz.explanation: DRY: Don't Repeat Yourself. If you're copying code, create a function instead. Write once, use many times. Professional programming practice.

quiz.question: What does 'return' do?
options: Sends value back to caller and stops function execution
quiz.explanation: 'return' sends value back to whoever called the function and stops execution. Code after return doesn't run. Functions without return give None.

sections.content: Lists store multiple values in single variable. Instead of score1, score2, score3... you have scores = [85, 92, 78]. Lists are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicates. One of most used data structures in Python. Master lists, you can handle most data manipulation tasks.

sections.title: Creating and Accessing Lists
items: Create: numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
Mixed types: mixed = [1, 'hello', 3.14, True]
Empty list: empty = [] or empty = list()
Indexing: numbers[0] gets first item (starts at 0!)
Negative indexing: numbers[-1] gets last item
Length: len(numbers) returns number of items
First item is index 0, not 1 (common mistake)

sections.content: Zero-based indexing: Python counts from 0, not 1. First item is index 0, second is index 1, etc. This trips up beginners but becomes natural. Negative indices count from end: -1 is last, -2 is second-to-last.

sections.title: Modifying Lists
items: Append: numbers.append(6) adds to end
Insert: numbers.insert(0, 99) adds at specific position
Remove: numbers.remove(3) removes first occurrence of value
Pop: numbers.pop() removes and returns last item
Pop index: numbers.pop(0) removes item at index 0
Change: numbers[0] = 100 changes first item
Clear: numbers.clear() removes all items

sections.title: List Slicing
items: Syntax: list[start:end:step]
Example: numbers[1:4] gets items at index 1, 2, 3 (not 4!)
From start: numbers[:3] gets first 3 items
To end: numbers[2:] gets from index 2 to end
Copy: numbers[:] creates copy of entire list
Reverse: numbers[::-1] reverses list
Step: numbers[::2] gets every 2nd item

sections.content: Lists are mutable: You can change them after creation. This differs from strings (immutable). Mutability is powerful but requires awareness: if you pass list to function and function modifies it, original list changes. Sometimes you want copy instead.

sections.title: List Methods
items: sort(): numbers.sort() sorts in place (modifies original)
sorted(): sorted(numbers) returns sorted copy (original unchanged)
reverse(): numbers.reverse() reverses in place
count(): numbers.count(5) counts occurrences of 5
index(): numbers.index(3) finds position of first 3
extend(): numbers.extend([6,7,8]) adds multiple items
in operator: 5 in numbers checks if 5 exists in list

sections.title: Common List Patterns
items: Iterate: for item in numbers: print(item)
Check existence: if 5 in numbers:
Sum: total = sum(numbers)
Max/min: highest = max(numbers), lowest = min(numbers)
Concatenate: list1 + list2 combines lists
Multiply: [0] * 5 creates [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]
List comprehension: [x*2 for x in numbers] (covered later)

quiz.question: What index is the first item in a list?
quiz.explanation: Python uses zero-based indexing. First item is index 0, second is index 1, etc. This is standard in most programming languages.

quiz.question: What does numbers.append(5) do?
options: Adds 5 to the end of the list
quiz.explanation: append() adds item to END of list. To add at specific position, use insert(). To add multiple items, use extend().
